title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Finance executives are lamenting being frozen out of plans to bolster America's dilapidated infrastructure, as the Biden administration pushes a tax-and-spend approach to building projects.

President Joe Biden's “American jobs plan”, unveiled last month, calls for $2tn of investment in highways, electrical grids and other basic infrastructure.

At the same time, the White House put forward corporate tax reforms that it said would generate enough money to pay for the investment spree within 15 years.

That has disappointed some investors and asset managers who once expected public-private partnerships would be a lucrative financing opportunity.

“I would love to put money into infrastructure projects,” said Christopher Ailman, chief investment officer of Calstrs, the retirement system that pays the pensions of California teachers. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The EU is working on a three-pronged approach to raise €13bn-€15bn of revenue a year to service the borrowing that it will start to issue this year under a €750bn recovery plan. Meanwhile, after a slow start Europe's vaccination drive is stepping up a gear.

  • Chinese state media rushed to defend locally developed coronavirus vaccines after a rare official acknowledgment of difficulties facing China's vaccination programme. Over the weekend the head of China's Center for Disease Control and Prevention raised the prospect of mixing vaccines and varying doses to boost efficacy.

  • India's second Covid-19 wave is spooking jittery consumers and threatening the country's economic recovery.

  • The rise in prices across Brazil is adding an extra layer of complexity to the country's fight against coronavirus, which has already claimed the lives of almost 350,000 individuals and pushed hospital services to the brink.

  • Big US companies, including Morgan Stanley, Yum Brands and PepsiCo, expanded private jet privileges for top executives because of coronavirus.

Follow our live blog for the latest Covid-19 news.

In the news

UK government to announce probe into Cameron and Greensill The UK government is set to announce an independent investigation into the lobbying scandal involving David Cameron and Greensill Capital, a now collapsed finance company. The inquiry will examine the former prime minister's contacts with ministers, officials and special advisers, senior officials said on Monday. (FT)

Jay Powell says the US economy is at an ‘inflection point' Speaking on CBS's 60 Minutes programme, the chair of the Federal Reserve delivered an upbeat message about the economic outlook for the US economy and underscored the critical importance of the ongoing vaccinations campaign. (FT)

Microsoft nears deal for voice tech pioneer Nuance Microsoft is nearing a deal to buy voice recognition pioneer Nuance Communications that would value the artificial intelligence company at about $16bn, according to people briefed about the matter. The deal would be Microsoft's second-largest acquisition ever. (FT)

Alibaba shares jump Alibaba shares rose sharply on Monday after the ecommerce group, founded by billionaire Jack Ma, said a record $2.8bn fine at the weekend marked the end of an antitrust investigation into the company. Chinese regulators announced the fine, which was equivalent to 4 per cent of the company's 2019 revenues, at the weekend. (FT)

Police killing near Minneapolis sparks unrest Tear gas has been fired and a curfew imposed amid angry protests after police fatally shot a black man, identified by relatives as 20-year-old Daunte Wright, in Brooklyn Center, just north of Minneapolis. The killing was just hours before the trial of Derek Chauvin, the police officer accused of killing George Floyd, was due to begin its third week. (FT, BBC)

US chief executives discuss co-ordinated response to voting laws Executives from some of America's biggest companies joined together at the weekend to oppose contentious voting legislation bills that have been introduced in 47 states, defying pressure from Republicans for business to stay out of politics. (FT)

EU and UK edge towards accord on trade rules for Northern Ireland The UK and the EU are making progress in talks on how to apply post-Brexit trade rules in Northern Ireland, raising hopes of an agreement as tensions have spilled over into violence on the streets of Belfast. (FT)

Iran calls Natanz blackout ‘nuclear terrorism' The head of Iran's Atomic Energy Agency said a blackout at the underground Natanz site, the country's main nuclear enrichment facility, was caused by those “who intend to prevent our nuclear industry's development”, without blaming any individual country or giving any details of the damage caused by the attack. (FT)

HSBC agrees to produce documents in Meng Wanzhou extradition row The US Department of Justice had obtained the documents from HSBC bank as part of its investigation into whether Huawei breached sanctions against Iran, resulting in the arrest of Meng Wanzhou, who is also the daughter of Huawei's founder, on charges of fraud.

  • Montenegro has asked the EU for assistance with paying a $1bn Chinese loan for an incomplete highway project that has imperilled the finances of the western Balkan nation. (FT)

The day ahead

US executives discuss chip shortage Senior executives from companies including Ford, GM and Intel will meet Biden administration officials on Monday to discuss the global chip shortage that has led to halted production at several factories. (WSJ)

England lockdown eases Millions will head for the shops, hairdressers and gyms on Monday as England eases the rules of its third lockdown. Britons have amassed an extra £180bn in bank accounts, equivalent to almost 10 per cent of the UK's annual gross domestic product, during several lockdowns. (FT)

What else we're reading

‘I'm concerned that what is being done is substantially excessive' Former treasury secretary Larry Summers tells Martin Wolf that the scale of Joe Biden's fiscal policy could lead to overheating and wasted resources. This is the latest in our Economist Exchange collection of interviews in which leading FT commentators talk to economists about what recovery from the pandemic looks like. (FT)

  • The World Bank and IMF were excoriated in the 1980s and ‘90s for making the poor pay for basic health provision or presuming that deficits were bad for growth. Their conversion, on display at last week's spring meetings, could put Saul of Tarsus to shame, writes Martin Sandbu.

Can CVC pull off a $20bn ‘deal of the century' at Toshiba? The proposed management buyout looks like an improbable win for the Japanese conglomerate's embattled chief. Toshiba's internal machinations have led people close to the company to interpret it as a sign of a much deeper power struggle within the 146-year-old group. (FT)

Why manufacturing matters to economic superpowers US and European companies are under tremendous pressure to boycott Xinjiang cotton and use homegrown alternatives. While they risk a backlash from Beijing, the textile industry has also been becoming less globalised for some time, writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

China's ‘wolf warriors' refuse to back down Beijing's foreign policy is raising tensions and threatening an EU trade deal but a new approach is unlikely. Chinese diplomats continue to openly clash with their international counterparts. Our editorial board writes that boycotting the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics is not the answer. (FT)

Why so many parliaments remain toxic workplaces Workplaces do not get much more hostile than a parliament. By design, they are full of active combatants eager to do each other in, writes Pilita Clark. They also have a lot more men than women, and what researchers call an “organisational climate” that effectively tolerates harassment. (FT)

FT & McKinsey Business Book of the Year 2021 To celebrate the launch of this year's Financial Times and McKinsey Business Book of the Year Award, we asked longlisted, shortlisted and winning authors to choose a book to add to a post-pandemic reading list. (FT)

Video of the day

What does ESG-friendly really mean? Environmental, social and governance-focused indices advanced 40 per cent in 2019-20. But what counts as ESG is far from straightforward, says FT data journalist Brooke Fox. (FT)
